metadata.titleEn: Spatial distribution of Active Layer Thickness and Soil Freeze Depth in Qilian Mountain
metadata.description: The widely definition of seasonally frozen ground include seasonally frozen layer (seasonally frozen ground regions) and seasonally thaw layer (active layer in permafrost regions). So the area extent of seasonally frozen ground occupied more than 80% land surface over Northern Hemisphere. Soil freeze/thaw cycle is one special character of seasonally frozen ground, which covers area extent, depth, time duration, variation of soil freeze/thaw. These changes in seasonally frozen ground have substantial impacts on energy, water and carbon exchange between the atmosphere and the land surface, surface and sub-surface hydrologic processes, vegetation growth, the ecosystem, carbon dioxide cycle, agriculture, and engineering constructuion, as a whole.Based on the observations from sites, CRU air temperature, we used the Stefan solution to calculate the spatial distribution of active layer thickness and soil freeze depth during 1971-2000. These results are helpful to further study the physical mechanism between seasonally frozen ground and climate change, eco-hydrology process.

background: Variability of active layer thickness (ALT) in permafrost regions is critical for assessments of climate change, water resources, and engineering applications. Detailed knowledge of ALT variations is also important for studies on ecosystem, hydrological, and geomorphological processes in cold regions. The combined land and ocean surface air temperatures increased 0.858C from 1880 to 2012 (IPCC 2013). Compared to the global mean, the rate and magnitude of temperature rise were much greater in high-latitude and high-altitude regions. This temperature rise has resulted in worldwide permafrost degradation, including an increase in active layer thickness (ALT). These ALT changes in permafrost regions can subsequently affect geomorphic processes, hydrologic processes, land cover and vegetation, infrastructure, and the sustainability of northern communities. ALT is an important indicator of climate change in permafrost regions. Previous studies have developed several ground-based measurement methods to determine ALT at the point scale by using mechanical probing, thaw tubes, and ground temperature measured in boreholes. At the regional scale, some indirect measurements of ALT have been developed using, for example, remote sensing and modeling techniques. Changes in ALT have been reported at regional, hemispheric, and global scales (IPCC 2013). Climatic factors play a dominant role in accounting for the spatial and temporal variability of ALT at all scales, but nonclimatic factors such as vegetation cover, soil properties, and environmental factors are also critical.
research objective: The primary objective of this study is therefore to provide a comprehensive 1971–2000 climatology of ALT and its changes across the entire Northern Hemisphere from 1850 through 2100.
challenges: Applying the concept of the edaphic factor would simplify the ALT estimation. However, the new challenge is to obtain reliable E-factor values because it is very difficult to obtain each parameter on the right-hand side of Eq.(6). Although some biases in the E factor using the simplified Stefan solution produce uncertainties in the ALT estimate, the standard deviation of the E factor and the ALT verification between observed and simulated data suggest that the simplified Stefan solution can be effectively used for ALT calculations at the hemisphere scale (Anisimov et al. 1997).
methods: To accomplish this, in situ observations, the Stefan solution based on a thawing index, and the edaphic factor (E factor) are employed to calculate ALT. The thawing index is derived from (i) the multimodel ensemble mean of 16 models from phase 5 of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5) over 1850–2005, (ii) three representative concentration pathways (RCP2.6, RCP4.5, and RCP8.5) for 2006–2100, and (iii) Climatic Research Unit (CRU) gridded observations for 1901–2014.
dataset: The Climatic Research Unit (CRU) version 3.23 time series dataset of surface air temperature is developed by the University of East Anglia (https://crudata.uea.ac.uk/cru/data/hrg/cru_ts_3.23/ ). We used air temperature output from 16 models from phase 5 of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5), developed by various international research institutions (Table 1; https://esgf-node.llnl.gov/projects/esgf-llnl/; Joetzjer et al. 2013). We assembled ALT observations from the Circumpolar Active Layer Monitoring Network (CALM) (Brown et al. 2000), the Global Terrestrial Network for Permafrost (GTN-P), meteorological stations in Russia including long-term records of soil temperature (Gilichinsky et al. 1998), and long-term field monitoring sites on the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau (Table 2).
findings: The results show significant spatial variability in in situ ALT that generally ranges from 40 to 320 cm, with some extreme values of 900 cm in the Alps. The differences in the ALT climatology between the three RCPs and the historical experiments ranged from 0 to 200 cm. The biggest increases, of 120–200 cm, are on the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau, while the smallest increases of less than 20 cm are in Alaska. Averaged over all permafrost regions, mean ALT from CMIP5 increased significantly at 0.576 0.04 cm decade21 during 1850–2005, while 2006–2100 projections show ALT increases of 0.776 0.08 cm decade21 for RCP2.6, 2.566 0.07 cm decade21 for RCP4.5, and 6.516 0.07 cm decade21 for RCP8.5.

background: The response of seasonal soil freeze depth to climate change has repercussions for the surface energy and water balance, ecosystems, the carbon cycle, and soil nutrient exchange. Despite its importance, the response of soil freeze depth to climate change is largely unknown. Frozen ground is an important component of the cryosphere. Permafrost regions underlay approximately 24% of the exposed land surface of the Northern Hemisphere, and seasonally frozen ground (SFG) regions occupy 57%. China has the third-largest frozen ground extent in the world, with a permafrost area of ∼2.20 × 10^6 km^2, or approximately 23% of its land area, mainly on the Tibetan Plateau; regions with SFG occupy about 50% of the land area in China. Under warming climate conditions, frozen ground regions are vulnerable to subsidence, especially ice-rich permafrost and relatively warm discontinuous permafrost. Maximum soil freeze depth (SFD) of SFG and active layer depth over permafrost play a significant role in cold environments, and all hydrological, ecological, biological, and pedological activities occur within this layer. Simultaneously, SFD influences the surface and subsurface hydrologic cycle, promotes soil texture changes, and alters the availability of soil nutrients for plant growth. The soil freeze–thaw cycle and SFD variations affect the decomposition of soil organic matter and greenhouse gas exchanges between the land surface and the atmosphere. Thus, seasonal SFD variability and climate are closely linked. Due to global climate warming, significant efforts have been devoted to permafrost research, such as permafrost variations on the hemispheric-scale permafrost temperature changes, permafrost degradation, hydrological processes in permafrost regions, feedbacks to climate change, and other aspects.

The freezing and thawing index can also be an important indicator to assess the variations in frozen ground. There are two primary types of freezing and thawing indices: the surface freezing and thawing index, calculated from ground surface temperatures, and the air freezing and thawing index, computed from air temperatures. Various methods are available to calculate the soil freeze depth. For example, it can be estimated directly from soil temperature, from physical and statistical models, and based on the Stefan solution. Soil freeze–thaw depth changes involve a series of interactions, such as energy exchanges, soil moisture exchanges, and gas exchanges between the atmospheric and terrestrial system. Therefore, variations of soil freeze–thaw most likely have an important effect on geomorphic, hydrological, and biological processes. Similarly, soil freeze–thaw depth changes also have destabilizing effects on engineering structures, such as on improperly constructed infrastructure. The freezing and thawing indices represent the accumulated negative and positive degree days in the cold and warm seasons, respectively. Temperature – including MAGST and MAAT – at the 839 station locations exhibits a statistically significant increase over the 1951–2013 period of 0.019 and 0.013 ◦C yr−1, or approximately 1.2 ◦C and 0.78 ◦C over the 63 years, respectively. The positive and negative correlation between SFD and FI and TI was statistically significant, consistent with previous results in other regions.
research objective: Therefore, using long-term observational data, the goals and unique contributions of this study are (1) to estimate the spatial and temporal variations of seasonal SFD across China, (2) to quantify the potential forcing factors of SFD including climatic and environmental factors, and (3) to establish how SFD variability responds to climate change in China.

In this study, we use the Stefan solution to estimate soil freeze depth. To estimate the SFD at the regional scale across China, we first calculate SFD for every observational station by interpolating the depth of the 0 ◦C isotherm throughout the 0.0–3.2 m soil profile using the daily mean soil temperature. To explore the possible variables leading to the documented changes in SFD, we analyze potentially important factors for soil freeze dynamics: latitude, altitude, MAAT, MAGST, freezing index including FIa and the ground surface freezing index (FIs), thawing index including the air (TIa) and ground surface thawing index (TIs), SND, and NDVI.
challenges: Shiklomanov (2012) similarly pointed out that SFG has not received much attention despite its vast area extent and importance, mainly due to a lack of long-term observational time series to document changes.
methods: To improve the original 0.5 ◦×0.5◦ MMGAT data to a 1 km resolution, spatial interpolation was used in conjunction with monthly lapse rates and the 1 km resolution DEM. The data processing steps are to (1) calculate the average monthly atmospheric lapse rate based on all available meteorological stations across China and their elevations; (2) bring each average monthly gridded air temperature value to a reference level (elevation of 0 m) using the average monthly lapse rate; (3) apply a Kriging interpolation to the reference-level adjusted MMGAT; and (4) bring the gridded reference-level air temperature back to the DEM-gridded height. To estimate the SFD at the regional scale across China, we first calculate SFD for every observational station by interpolating the depth of the 0 ◦C isotherm throughout the 0.0–3.2 m soil profile using the daily mean soil temperature. Next, we estimate the FIa based on the calculations in Frauenfeld et al. (2007). To estimate the E value for all stations, we use the SFD, FIa, and Eqs. (2) and (3). Then, we interpolate the E value to the regional scale at 1 km resolution using kriging in ArcGIS. The SFD is estimated across China based on Eq. (4), the 1 km E value, and FIa. We can then estimate the regional-scale SFD for each year from 1950 to 2009 across China and obtain the mean decadal SFD. Finally, we estimate the SFD trend at the regional scale across China based on regression analysis. To evaluate the result, we compare the observational SFD calculated from the soil temperatures and the simulated SFD derived from the Stefan method (Eq. 4) in Fig. 3.
dataset: Several datasets are used including daily air and ground surface temperature, daily soil temperature at 0–320 cm depth, mean monthly gridded air temperature, and daily snow depth. Mean daily air temperature and ground surface temperature data are collected from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) for a total of 839 meteorological stations available four times daily at 02:00, 08:00, 14:00, and 20:00. Daily soil temperature data are available for 845 sites across China from the CMA, measured at the depths of 0.00, 0.05, 0.1, 0.15, 0.2, 0.4, 0.5, 0.8, 1.6, and 3.2 m. Mean monthly gridded air temperature was used to analyze soil freeze depth at the regional scale across China. We obtained the University of Delaware’s 1900–2014 terrestrial air temperature gridded monthly time series, with a 0.5°×0.5° spatial resolution. Considering the complex terrain across China and the impacts of elevation on air temperature, we also used the global 30 arcsec elevation dataset (GTOPO30) as the DEM for this study to further improve the MMGAT resolution. We obtained daily mean snow depth data for 672 sites across China. The NDVI dataset used in this study is produced by the Global Inventory Modeling and Mapping Studies (GIMMS) team, available for 1982–2006. It is derived from NOAA AVHRR data, available at 15-day temporal resolution and an 8 km spatial resolution.

Based on more than 800 sites, we evaluated the interpolated MMGAT against the observational monthly air temperatures and found that the regression coefficient was almost 1.0 with a minimum of 0.98 in April. A number of climatic and environmental variables including MAAT, mean annual ground surface temperature (MAGST), freezing index, thawing index, SND, and NDVI are selected to investigate the potential drivers of the observed long-term SFD changes across China. Based on the sites’ E factors and FI a, we calculate SFD time series anomalies from 1951 to 2012. Although a composite time series of all available stations data can be calculated during 1951–2012, few of 839 stations actually contribute to the mean values before the 1960s.
findings: Results show that soil freeze depth decreased significantly at a rate of −0.18 ±0.03 cm yr−1, resulting in a net decrease of 8.05 ±1.5 cm over 1967–2012 across China. On the regional scale, soil freeze depth decreases varied between 0.0 and 0.4 cm yr−1 in most parts of China during 1950–2009. By investigating potential climatic and environmental driving factors of soil freeze depth variability, we find that mean annual air temperature and ground surface temperature, air thawing index, ground surface thawing index, and vegetation growth are all negatively associated with soil freeze depth. Changes in snow depth are not correlated with soil freeze depth. Air and ground surface freezing indices are positively correlated with soil freeze depth. Comparing these potential driving factors of soil freeze depth, we find that freezing index and vegetation growth are more strongly correlated with soil freeze depth, while snow depth is not significant. We conclude that air temperature increases are responsible for the decrease in seasonal freeze depth.

There is a statistically significant change in SFD anomalies of−0.18 ±0.03 cm yr−1, corresponding to a net decrease of 8.05 ±1.5 cm. The result demonstrates that the mean absolute error and root-mean-square error are 0.08 and 0.14 m, respectively, indicating that there is a good agreement between simulated and observational SFD. As is expected from climate warming, a statistically significant decreasing trend in SFD is evident across China from 1950 to 2009. The negative relationship between SFD and NDVI indicates the effect of vegetation on SFD as well as their inverse relationship.

Definition.Question: What is the Stefan solution and how is it used in estimating active layer thickness or soil freeze depth in permafrost regions?
Definition.Answer: The Stefan solution is a method used to estimate the active layer thickness (ALT) or soil freeze depth by applying a thawing index derived from climatic data. It involves the use of a thawing index, which is calculated from air or ground surface temperatures, and is adjusted by an edaphic factor to account for soil properties. This approach allows for the estimation of ALT or soil freeze depth at various scales, from point measurements to regional assessments.

Definition.Question: What are the potential challenges associated with using remote sensing and modeling techniques for measuring active layer thickness in permafrost areas?
Definition.Answer: Remote sensing and modeling techniques for measuring active layer thickness face challenges such as obtaining reliable edaphic factor values, which are difficult to measure accurately. Additionally, these methods may include biases and uncertainties in the estimates due to the simplified assumptions in models like the Stefan solution. Factors such as vegetation cover, soil properties, and environmental conditions also introduce variability and complexity in these measurements.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods for estimating active layer thickness (ALT) using the Stefan solution compare to those used for estimating soil freeze depth (SFD) in terms of data requirements and accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: Both the Stefan solution for ALT and the method for estimating SFD rely on temperature indices, such as thawing and freezing indices, and require in situ temperature data. However, ALT estimation also uses multimodel ensemble data from projects like CMIP5, whereas SFD estimation relies on daily soil temperature profiles and spatial interpolation techniques. While both approaches apply the Stefan solution, differences in data granularity and interpolation methods may lead to variability in accuracy and data requirements between the two.

Comparison.Question: How do challenges in obtaining reliable 'E-factor' values for ALT estimation compare to those faced in interpolating soil freeze depth (SFD) data in the context of spatial resolution improvements?
Comparison.Answer: Both ALT and SFD estimations face challenges related to data accuracy and resolution. The E-factor for ALT estimation is challenging due to the difficulty in obtaining reliable parameters, which can introduce biases and uncertainties. Similarly, improving SFD spatial resolution involves complex interpolation methods like kriging, requiring accurate lapse rates and elevation data. Both challenges highlight issues of data reliability and the need for precise environmental parameters in improving the accuracy of spatial estimations.

Interpretation.Question: How do researchers account for variability in active layer thickness across different permafrost regions using data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Researchers use ground-based measurement methods such as mechanical probing, thaw tubes, and ground temperature measured in boreholes at the point scale. At the regional scale, they employ indirect measurements using remote sensing and modeling techniques, accounting for climatic and nonclimatic factors like vegetation cover and soil properties.

Interpretation.Question: What are the key challenges in ensuring the accuracy of soil freeze depth estimates in varying climatic conditions, and how might these be addressed using available datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: One key challenge is obtaining reliable values for factors like the edaphic factor, which affects the accuracy of estimates. This can be addressed by using long-term observational data, spatial interpolation techniques, and regression analysis to refine estimates and validate them against observational data. Datasets from meteorological stations and global temperature datasets help in addressing these challenges.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies are effective for modeling the impact of climate change on seasonal frozen ground variability, and what datasets support these analyses?
Interpretation.Answer: Effective methodologies include using the Stefan solution for estimating soil freeze depth and analyzing potential forcing factors such as climatic and environmental variables. Datasets that support these analyses include daily and monthly air and ground temperature data, soil temperature profiles, snow depth data, and vegetation indices from sources like the China Meteorological Administration and global databases.

The simplification of the Stefan solution introduces biases, contributing to uncertainties in ALT estimates.

This oversight limits the understanding and documentation of its changes over time.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the decrease in seasonal soil freeze depth across China, and how do climatic and environmental factors contribute to this trend?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The decrease in seasonal soil freeze depth across China is primarily caused by rising air temperatures. Climatic factors such as mean annual air temperature and ground surface temperature, along with environmental factors like vegetation growth, negatively correlate with soil freeze depth, contributing to its reduction. The freezing index and vegetation growth are more strongly correlated with soil freeze depth changes, while snow depth is not significant.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using the Stefan solution and edaphic factor in estimating active layer thickness (ALT) on the accuracy and reliability of data across large geographical regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using the Stefan solution and edaphic factor can simplify the estimation of ALT, but challenges include obtaining reliable E-factor values. Despite some biases and uncertainties in the E factor, the simplified Stefan solution can be effectively used for ALT calculations on a hemispheric scale, as suggested by the standard deviation of the E factor and the ALT verification between observed and simulated data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the impact of employing a variety of environmental and climatic datasets on the estimation of soil freeze depth (SFD) and understanding its variability over time?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing a variety of environmental and climatic datasets, such as air and ground surface temperature, soil temperature, and indices like the freezing and thawing index, allows for a comprehensive analysis of SFD variability. This approach can reveal correlations between SFD and factors like air temperature, vegetation growth, and freezing indices, helping to identify the driving forces behind observed long-term changes in SFD across regions like China.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use long-term observational data to estimate soil freeze depth across China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using long-term observational data is important for estimating soil freeze depth (SFD) across China to understand the spatial and temporal variations of seasonal SFD, quantify potential forcing factors including climatic and environmental influences, and establish how SFD variability responds to climate change. This approach provides insights into the repercussions of climate change on surface energy and water balance, ecosystems, and the carbon cycle.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in estimating soil freeze depth at a regional scale using observational data in cold regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To estimate soil freeze depth at the regional scale, one can calculate it for every observational station by interpolating the depth of the 0°C isotherm throughout the soil profile using daily mean soil temperature. This involves analyzing factors such as latitude, altitude, mean annual air temperature, ground surface temperature, freezing index, thawing index, snow depth, and NDVI. Spatial interpolation is applied to improve resolution, and kriging can be used to interpolate values at a finer scale. The trend can then be analyzed using regression techniques.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can datasets from various international and regional sources be integrated to study active layer thickness changes over time?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Datasets from international and regional sources such as the Climatic Research Unit, CMIP5 models, and the Circumpolar Active Layer Monitoring Network can be integrated by collecting air temperature outputs and long-term soil temperature records from meteorological stations. These datasets can be combined using modeling techniques and in situ observations, applying the Stefan solution and thawing indices to calculate active layer thickness changes over time. The integration requires careful harmonization of data formats and temporal scales.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the accurate estimation of active layer thickness and seasonal freeze depth in permafrost regions?
Enablement.Answer: Data collection methods such as in situ observations, mechanical probing, thaw tubes, ground temperature measurements in boreholes, and remote sensing techniques enable the accurate estimation of active layer thickness and seasonal freeze depth in permafrost regions.

Enablement.Question: How do climatic and environmental factors influence the development of datasets for understanding seasonal soil freeze depth variability?
Enablement.Answer: Climatic and environmental factors such as mean annual air temperature, ground surface temperature, air thawing index, ground surface thawing index, and vegetation growth influence the development of datasets for understanding seasonal soil freeze depth variability, as these factors are critical in assessing the potential drivers of soil freeze dynamics.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be difficulties in obtaining reliable E-factor values when estimating active layer thickness (ALT) using the Stefan solution?
Expectation.Answer: Obtaining reliable E-factor values is challenging because it is very difficult to acquire each parameter required on the right-hand side of the equation used in the Stefan solution, leading to potential biases and uncertainties in the ALT estimate.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to the limited attention given to seasonally frozen ground (SFG) despite its vast area extent and importance?
Expectation.Answer: One significant factor is the lack of long-term observational time series that can document changes in seasonally frozen ground, which affects the extent of attention and research dedicated to this area.

Expectation.Question: Why might changes in snow depth not correlate with soil freeze depth when investigating climatic and environmental driving factors?
Expectation.Answer: Changes in snow depth are not correlated with soil freeze depth because other factors such as mean annual air temperature, ground surface temperature, and vegetation growth have a more pronounced impact on soil freeze depth, overshadowing the influence of snow depth.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the challenges associated with obtaining reliable E-factor values in the estimation of active layer thickness (ALT) across different permafrost regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Obtaining reliable E-factor values is challenging because it is difficult to obtain each parameter required by the Stefan solution. Biases in the E-factor can produce uncertainties in ALT estimates, although the verification between observed and simulated data suggests that the simplified Stefan solution can effectively be used for hemisphere-scale ALT calculations.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the effectiveness of using the Stefan solution to estimate soil freeze depth (SFD) across China, particularly in terms of its spatial interpolation techniques?
Judgmental.Answer: The Stefan solution is effective in estimating SFD across China, particularly when combined with spatial interpolation techniques such as kriging, which improves the resolution from 0.5°×0.5° to 1 km. This method takes into account the complex terrain and impacts of elevation on air temperature, allowing for detailed regional-scale SFD estimates.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential limitations of using long-term observational datasets from meteorological stations to study seasonal freeze depth (SFD) variations in China?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential limitations include a lack of long-term observational time series to document changes, especially before the 1960s, as few stations contribute to the mean values during earlier periods. Additionally, while the datasets provide valuable climatic and environmental variables, the spatial coverage and density of stations may not fully capture the variability in complex terrains or remote regions.

Assertion.Question: I'm uncertain about how to effectively use remote sensing and modeling techniques for measuring active layer thickness at a regional scale.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing and modeling techniques can be used to measure active layer thickness by leveraging data from multimodel ensemble means, such as those from the CMIP5 models, and gridded observations like those from the CRU dataset. These methods allow for the estimation of thawing indices which, when combined with ground-based observations, can provide a comprehensive assessment of active layer thickness across large regions.

Assertion.Question: I don't fully understand the challenges involved in obtaining reliable edaphic factor values for calculating active layer thickness.
Assertion.Answer: Obtaining reliable edaphic factor values is challenging because it requires precise data for each parameter involved in the Stefan solution equation. Biases in these values can lead to uncertainties in the active layer thickness estimates. Despite these challenges, the standard deviation of the edaphic factor and verification between observed and simulated data suggest that the simplified Stefan solution can be effectively used at large scales.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure how to accurately interpolate soil freeze depth data across a region with complex terrain.
Assertion.Answer: Accurately interpolating soil freeze depth data across complex terrain involves using spatial interpolation techniques such as Kriging, combined with high-resolution digital elevation models (DEMs). By calculating average monthly atmospheric lapse rates and adjusting air temperature values to a reference level, one can then interpolate the data to match the terrain's elevation, allowing for more accurate regional-scale estimations of soil freeze depth.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore various data collection methods used to determine the active layer thickness and soil freeze depth in permafrost regions, and discuss their advantages and limitations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Ground-based measurement methods such as mechanical probing, thaw tubes, and ground temperature measured in boreholes are commonly used at the point scale for determining active layer thickness (ALT). At the regional scale, indirect measurements using remote sensing and modeling techniques are employed. In situ observations, the Stefan solution based on a thawing index, and the edaphic factor (E factor) are also used to calculate ALT. For soil freeze depth (SFD), it can be estimated directly from soil temperature, from physical and statistical models, and based on the Stefan solution.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in obtaining reliable data for modeling active layer thickness and soil freeze depth, and suggest potential solutions to these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include obtaining reliable E-factor values for the Stefan solution, as it is difficult to obtain each parameter involved. There are biases in the E factor using the simplified Stefan solution, which introduce uncertainties in the ALT estimate. A lack of long-term observational time series for documenting changes in seasonally frozen ground is also a challenge. Solutions could include improving data collection techniques and increasing the number of observational stations to provide more comprehensive datasets for analysis.
